title: Post-COVID Myalgia and Fatigue in a Middle-Aged Office Worker
clinical_history: Mr. Daniel Li is a 48-year-old accountant who contracted Coronavirus (COVID-19) seven weeks ago. He experienced moderate respiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath, and fever, requiring 5 days of hospital admission but no intensive care. Two weeks following acute illness, he developed persistent, diffuse muscle aches and profound fatigue. He complains of deep aching pain primarily in his thighs and shoulder girdle, with milder discomfort in the lumbar region. He reports difficulty climbing stairs, standing from a seated position, and lifting moderate weights due to both pain and subjective weakness. He experiences heightened symptoms following minimal exertion, necessitating rest periods throughout the workday. He describes his pain as constant but fluctuating, with notable exacerbation in the evening.
aggrevating_factors: physical activity (walking >10 minutes, stair climbing), prolonged sitting, lifting objects, stress, poor sleep
picture: Patient highlights both thighs and shoulders as primary pain zones with secondary discomfort in lower back. Appearance is fatigued, uses handrails when climbing stairs, takes frequent rests.
easing_factors: Rest, gentle stretching, warm showers, acetaminophen. Brief naps (20â€“30min) offer some relief.
past_history: No significant musculoskeletal complaints before COVID-19 infection. Mild, well-controlled hypertension diagnosed 3 years ago.
medical_history: Hypertension, BMI 29, no previous respiratory or neuromuscular disorders.
medications: Lisinopril 10mg daily, acetaminophen 500mg as needed for pain (max 3x/day after COVID-19), daily multivitamin
personal_history: Lives with spouse, two teenage children. No tobacco. Low habitual activity prior to illness (sedentary job, occasional weekend walks). Reports heightened stress due to work demands and pandemic uncertainties.
imaging: None to date. Laboratory: Normal CBC and CK, negative for autoimmune markers.
